did.abstract: This collection contains documentation of the ivory industry, processing and trade in Ivoryton, CT during the years of operation of Comstock, Cheney & Co. and Pratt, Read & Co., successive names for the ivory factory which was the main employer in the village from the 1860's to the 1980's.

bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: The Ivory processing factory in Ivoryton, CT began as S.M. Comstock Co. in 1847. With the addition of inventory George Cheney in 1862, the company became Comstock, Cheney & Co., the company that was the dominant economic and social force in the town of Essex, CT. In Deep Rive, CT, the ivory factory Pratt, Read & Co. formed in 1863. The two factories merged in 1936, retaining the name of Pratt, Read & Co. and moving the operations to the Ivoryton plant.The Falls River Flood of 1982 caused extensive damage to the factory and the ivory ban of 1989 effectively ended the factory in Ivoryton. The company had diversified into other manufacturing industries and moved the company to Bridgeport, CT before finally declaring bankruptcy and closing for good in 2010.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: The collection includes documentation of the ivory industry, articles about ivory processing, annual reports, catalogs, shareholder reports, correspondence; correspondence related to Edith Deforest, secretary who also managed the company museum; correspondence related to Peter Comstock, president in 1930s-1980s, geneaological information about Comstock family and business correspondence, Cheney, Pratt Families, minutes, wills, mechanical drawings of machine parts produced by Cornwall & Patterson Co., small companies acquired after the piano industry began to wane, Comstock Cheney Ivoryton, corporate history, land records, invoices, financial papers, deeds, legal documents of the Pratt, Read & Company Deep River, Pratt, Read & Co. Ivoryton: articles, strike information, property records, building plans, scrapbooks, slides documenting the 1982 flood; photographs of Pratt, Read & Company Presidents; Pratt, Read & Co. annual reports (1892-1986); stock ledgers (1902-1930); the majority of the records document the history of these companies after their merger.
